description.narrative: Consortium for Advanced Research Training in Africa (CARTA) was established in 2008 by the African Population and Health Research Center (APHRC) and a group of international academic and research institutions. Its creation emanates from the understanding that Africa's progress depends on its "ability to understand, interpret, select, adapt, use, transmit, diffuse, produce and commercialise scientific and technological innovations in ways appropriate to culture, aspirations, and level of development". The overall intervention logic for CARTA is that funding multidisciplinary research in a number of different research institutes will increase critical mass and contribute to a sustainable longterm research capacity and assist to develop interventions to improve health outcomes in the region. It aims to achieve this via the development of vibrant, multidisciplinary research hubs at African universities, with regional networks of locally trained, internationally recognised scholars working together to address major public health challenges. CARTA currently comprises nine African partners between universities, four research institutes, and selected seven non-African partners with a history of successful collaboration with African academic institutions. Together, these institutions recognise that individual African universities and countries lack the requisite human and financial resources as well as infrastructural capacity to individually implement globally competitive doctoral programs. To achieve its goals CARTA aims to strengthen doctoral training and supervision in sub-Saharan Africa and to develop the institutional capacity of participating universities to conduct and lead internationally competitive cutting edge research on which to base population health policy and practise.

Forskningsprogrammet Consortium for Advanced Research Training in Africa (CARTA) grundades 2008 på initiativ av moderorganisationen African Population and Health Research Center (APHRC). CARTA är ett internationellt hälsoforsknings- och utbildnings-initiativ bestående av nio universitet och fyra forskningsinstitutioner från västra, östra, centrala och södra Afrika, samt utvalda icke-afrikanska institutioner, med huvudkontor i Nairobi, Kenya. Syftet med CARTA är att stärka den nationella forskningskapaciteten på afrikanska universitet för att möta efterfrågan av lokal kunskap och forskning inom prioriterade områden inom folkhälsa. I ett större perspektiv ämnas forskningsresultaten implementeras på policynivå och långsiktigt bidra till att etablera en levande forskningskultur i Afrika som är konkurrenskraftigt enligt internationella mått. CARTA:s primära roll är att bygga upp konkurrenskraftiga doktorandutbildningar som inkluderar utbildning av fakultetspersonal och handledare och som satsar på forskningsinstitutionernas infrastruktur. Sida ger institutionsstöd på totalt 38,2 MSEK för 2012-2015 varav 31,2 MSEK till CARTA (genom APHRC) för implementering av doktorandprogram-men och finansiering av doktorander, samt 7 MSEK till APHRC som institutionsstöd.
APHRC inkom i september 2014 med en ansökan till Sida om extra stöd för CARTA för år 2014. Begäran gäller finansiering för att CARTA ska kunna rekrytera ytterligare 25 forskare till den femte kohorten. Sida ser att ytterligare forskare kommer att föra CARTA närmare målet att bygga en kritisk massa av välutbildade forskare i hälsovetenskaper.

description.narrative: CARTA’s primary goal is to support doctoral training through a model collaborative PhD programme and to build a critical mass of highly competent researchers in the region. A total of 165 fellows are currently enrolled in the CARTA programme. From January 2011 to December 2016 there was a steady increase in the proportion of females admitted into CARTA PhD fellowship. By December 2016, the programme achieved gender balance with 87(53%) females and 78(47%) males. Several fellows are on the trajectory to become leaders in scientific research as exemplified by their publication record. Between January and December 2016, CARTA fellows published 88 papers in peer-reviewed journals with 51 as first authors. In total, by December 2016, they had published 421 papers. In utilizing CARTA network of partnering institutions and stakeholders, joint JAS curriculum development has led to improvements in seminar content and planning and provided an effective mechanism to incorporate participant feedback into subsequent seminars.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
